data.event: Windsor is a small historic unincorporated community located within Robbinsville Township (known as Washington Township until 2007) in Mercer County, New Jersey, United States.

event.title: was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1992

data.event: The community, covering 570 acres (230 ha), was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1992.
Founded in 1818, it was named Centerville because it was the geographical center of the state.

event.title: 1814, after the completion of the Bordentown and South Amboy stagecoach turnpike, William McKnight, director of the turnpike company, built

data.event: In 1814, after the completion of the Bordentown and South Amboy stagecoach turnpike, William McKnight, director of the turnpike company, built a tavern at the intersection of the turnpike and present-day Windsor-Perrineville Road.

event.title: 1816 the local section of the stagecoach turnpike between New York and Philadelphia ran

data.event: In 1816 the local section of the stagecoach turnpike between New York and Philadelphia ran along Main Street.

event.title: late 1831, the Camden and Amboy Railroad was constructed

data.event: In late 1831, the Camden and Amboy Railroad was constructed through Centerville.
It quickly became the largest village between Yardville (Sand Town) and Hightstown, and was renamed "Windsor" in 1846 to avoid any confusion with a Centerville post office in Hunterdon County.
